Her position in the othlor places her above scrutiny, allowing her actions to go unchecked.

Utilizing her communal binding mastery, Mishara has the ability to commune with hundreds and thousands of ants, spiders, and mites across the realm and outlying nations. These creatures act as spies and informants, allowing Mishara to collect seemingly impossible information from even the most secret of conversations. Her mastery of shared spellcasting allows her to cast spells through these insects, whether they are separated by inches or hundreds of miles. With careful focus and expert attention, Mishara secretly intervenes in dangerous situations across the realms; sometimes as a long-distance healer who saves a crucial figure from an expert assassination, other times as the magical assassin who removes a crucial threat to the Rashemi.

Despite her good intentions, Mishara's connections with the underground durthan witches, immense spy network, and access to dangerous and forbidden knowledge act as constant temptations to use her powers for ill. While the othlor's rigid rules and delineation of light and dark magics have historically held the wychlaran together and ensured the safety of Rashemen, Mishara has begun to question, once again, whether these rules are the correct path forward. With ever-evolving magical forces threatening invasion from Thay and the other bordering countries, it is unclear how Rashemen could survive without wychlaran who are willing to skirt the boundaries of magical law and reshape the rules that govern the wychlaran. Mishara's alliances and connections, whether for good or ill, may shape the future of Rashemen; as great powers rise and fall, knowledge is the true magic that holds this nation together.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day).
entries: If Raustulph fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Raustulph has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Ghost Dagger.
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Spectral Touch.
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d8}) necrotic damage but undead are immune to this damage. Additionally, Raustulph regains hit points equal to damage dealt.

action.name: Shapechanger
entries: Raustulph can use his action to polymorph into either a Medium cloud of mist or his spectral undead form. While in mist form, Raustulph can't take any actions, speak, or manipulate objects. He can hear, see, is weightless, has his usual flying speed, can hover, and can enter a hostile  creature's space and stop there (he usually does). If air can pass through a gap, so can Raustulph in mist form, without squeezing. He has advantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws, and is immune to all nonmagical damage except fire damage.

legendary.name: Cast Cantrip.
entries: Raustulph casts a cantrip.

legendary.name: Move
entries: Raustulph flies up to his speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Regeneration
entries: Raustulph regains 7 hit points.

legendary.name: Spectral Touch.
entries: Raustulph makes a spectral touch attack.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Raustulph is a 16th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 20}, +12 to hit with spell attacks). Raustulph has the following wizard spells prepared:

entries: A century ago, a Rashemaar wizard fought a spell-duel across Rashemen against three senior Red Wizards of Thay, all four combatants teleporting across the region as they fought. Raustulph was that mage, and he prevailed in the fray, destroying all three of his foes—but at the cost of his sanity and his life.

Caught in multiple snarling collisions of hostile battle-spells, Raustulph was torn into undeath, and has existed ever since as a fierce defender of Rashemen with a short attention span, a unique spectral undead who can suddenly coalesce out of mist or fog, or arise as mist from any body of water in Rashemen, and ride any wind, from the merest ghost of a breeze to a howling gale. He usually manifests to challenge intruders, unless they can convince him they mean Rashemen no harm.

Raustulph is utterly fearless (for no matter what happens to him, he manifests anew when the next phase of the moon begins), often vanishes as abruptly as he appeared, and if he takes a fancy to adventurers, will often spy on them and reappear repeatedly, whenever they need aid—or when he wants to thwart them.

The mage's spectral humanoid form is that of a legless, floating phantom who can see, speak, and cast spells as he did in later life—that is, hurling magics by calling on the Weave with verbal and somatic components but not needing material components at all.

Today, Raustulph roves Rashemen, concentrating on its border areas, as the self-appointed guardian of the land. He occasionally shows himself and speaks to the matriarchs, but usually acts as a lone wolf, appearing to outlanders and intruders. He is gruff and cantankerous, and all too apt to say such things as "Clowns and jesters are more welcome elsewhere than in this fair land" and "Competent and valiant base liars, are we?" and "You demonstrate a formidable talent for leaping into messes of your own creation" and "It's fortunate for you that I so deeply appreciate the entertainment you provide."

trait.name: Enthralling Performance
entries: If the satyr performs for at least 1 minute, it chooses up to four humanoids within 60 feet of it who watched or listened to the entire performance. Each target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed}. While {@condition charmed} in this way, the target idolizes the satyr and will take part in the satyr's revels. The {@condition charmed} condition ends for the creature after 1 hour, if it takes any damage, if the satyr attacks the target, or if the target witnesses the satyr attacking or damaging any of the target's allies.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The satyr has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Sleepless Reveler
entries: Magic can't put the satyr to sleep.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The satyr makes two ram attacks or two shortbow attacks.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 2d4 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

Outlanders that journey into Rashemen struggle with the customs and traditions of a harsh land. Allies are difficult to come by, but one that can be counted on wanders the shores of Lake Ashane, enjoying jhulid and sjorl, singing tales of the great heroes of old: the satyr Tarhil.

entries.name: Wandering Skald
entries: Always looking for a good time, Tarhil eagerly offers his services to those new to Rashemen who seek a guide, historian, or negotiator. He claims to be in good standing with the nature spirits who dwell amongst the land, favored even by the water spirit of Lake Ashane. Such statements have some level of truth to them due to the magical power Tarhil possesses. His songs and tunes lead to manifestations of the Weave, while other abilities seem to directly connect to magical blessings of the fey. Where these powers come from, and if he is connected to these spirits, Tarhil chooses not to say.

{@b Appearance.} Tarhil appears as a young, clean-faced satyr, with an appearance compared to a young human male. His eyes are a dazzling, otherworldly ice blue, as though blessed by the spirits of Lake Ashane itself. He carries with him the Warhorn of D'yobcire, a sign of his friendship with the Iron Lord. His main choice of musical instrument, however, is a set of panpipes that produce many scales and notes as he tells his tales of the battles fought on the shoreline of the Lake of Tears.

entries.name: Relations
entries: Through his wanderings Tarhil has encountered many legends who dwell within Rashemen. He has spoken with Stormwind, the ancient treant, about things long forgotten. Despite a solid relationship with Stormwind (when the treant is awake), he doesn't always see eye-to-eye with Andar Silverbirch, the treant's new liaison and intercessor. While Andar tends to be more cautious and serious, Tarhil is, like the majority of satyrs, carefree and sometimes flippant.

{@b Iron Lord Ally.} The Iron Lord and his berserker lodges see Tarhil as an ally, as he is known to embrace their feats of strength and endurance with raw gusto when he visits. Those journeying with Tarhil and failing to meet the same standards as the Tarhil find that he becomes a fickle ally, ready to abandon those whose actions can't match their boasting.

Tarhil gives all Wychlaran great respect and deference, going beyond normal traditions, paying them homage with fey traditions of gifting trinkets, secrets, and what some perceive to be garbage and waste.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The archmage is an 18th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks). The archmage can cast {@spell disguise self} and {@spell invisibility} at will and has the following wizard spells prepared:
footerEntries: *The archmage casts these spells on itself before combat.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The archmage has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

variant.name: Familiars
entries: Any spellcaster that can cast the {@spell find familiar} spell (such as an archmage or mage) is likely to have a familiar. The familiar can be one of the creatures described in the spell or some other Tiny monster, such as a {@creature crawling claw}, {@creature imp}, {@creature pseudodragon}, or {@creature quasit}.

For most of their youth Zasvor Temraid lived on the streets of Immilmar. When their magical abilities manifested in their early teens, they were pickpocketing a foreigner and nearly killed the man by electrocuting him. The city authorities quickly detained Zasvor and waited for the wychlaran to arrive. They were ferried away to the Urlingwood to receive the blessings of the spirits before being sequestered. Through this entire process, Zasvor barely spoke a word, stunned that they had nearly killed a man and even more so that they were an Old One.

Very quickly the other vremyonni and wychlaran realized not only were they a quick study of the craft, they were a prodigy pointing out flaws in old designs and ways to improve them. An eldritch engine that laid dormant for half a century was finally activated after Zasvor examined it for a few minutes.

Zasvor's prodigious skills only grew with age until they were looked upon as the most intelligent of all the vremyonni, both young and old. The hathran and othlor's frequently invited them to be a part of the decision-making process when it came to any and everything arcane. Sometime after they reached their

35th birthday, the othlor's blessed them with one of the greatest gifts a vremyonni can be given: longevity. Their lifespan now mirrored that of most elves. With their lifespan greatly expanded, there was nothing they couldn't learn, no great project they couldn't finish. All of Zasvor's time was dedicated to making better weapons of war to defend the Rashemi. Their behavior was that of a fervorous zealot.

It was because of their zealous fervor that their betrayal was all the more devastating. To this day, no one knows what drove them to betray all that they had held dear for nearly two and a half centuries. But one fateful day they turned on their fellow vremyonni, killing a number of them and Siradhal Nyenebotra, a well known hathran that was visiting. Zasvor stole a number of ancient texts and schema before teleporting away.

Three centuries later they are still wanted by the wychlaran. They proved rather elusive, constantly changing their appearance, traveling between demiplanes of their own creation and never staying in one location or plane for any extended length of time.

While Zasvor is constantly moving they have made powerful friends and allies since they've left Rashemen. The knowledge that they took with them has never been shared with any others as far as the wychlaran can tell. Those that come across them and aren't seeking to end their lives can persuade them to aid them if their cause is just or curious enough.

spell.name: Cohort
entries: You perform a ritual of bonding with another willing creature, tethering them to you and your magic. When you cast this spell, you and the target gain the benefits listed below:

items: When you and the target are forced to make a saving throw against the same spell, use either your or the target's result, whichever is higher.
When taking damage, either you or the target can use your reaction to gain resistance to that damage type if the other has resistance to that damage.
Spells and features that either you or the target use with a range of touch can target the other, as long as you are within 30 feet of each other and can see the target.

entries: This bonding ends early if either you or the target are reduced to 0 hit points, are ever on a different plane of existence for more than 1 hour, or if you cast this spell again and bond to a different creature.

m.text: two pints of jhuild worth 1 gp each, which the spell consumes

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: You can create a permanent bond by casting this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, targeting the same creature every day for one year. After doing so, this effect only ends if you or the bonded creature die.

spell.name: Enrage
entries: You touch a target, bestowing them with a fit of rage. An unwilling creature can make a Wisdom saving throw to resist this effect. When successful, the target becomes enraged, giving them advantage on any melee attack roll using Strength. Attacks made against the target by other creatures within 5 feet have advantage.

This effect ends early at the end of the enraged creature's turn if they have not dealt damage with a Strength-based attack since the start of their last turn, or if they are reduced to 0 hit points. The target can also attempt to end the effect early by making a Wisdom saving throw at the end of their turn (no action required).

spell.name: Flashburst
entries: You cause a blinding flash of light to erupt around one target creature within range. The target is {@condition blinded} for the duration and must make a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} for 1 round. Additionally, each creature within a 10-foot radius of the target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition blinded} for the duration. At the end of each of its turns, an affected creature can make a Constitution saving throw, ending the effect on themselves on a success.

components.m: a pinch of sulfur or phosphorus

spell.name: Moon Blade

m.text: a small candy made with wintergreen oil

entries: You evoke a blazing sword of moonlight into your hand. The moon blade is a simple weapon with which you are proficient. It deals {@damage 3d8} radiant damage on a hit and has the finesse and light properties. The blade deals an additional {@damage 2d8} radiant damage to undead on a hit.

Targets struck by the moon blade have difficulty maintaining or casting spells. Creatures have disadvantage on concentration checks made against damage from the moon blade. Additionally, until the end of the target's next turn, targets must succeed on a saving throw using their spellcasting ability to cast a spell, or their spell fails and has no effect.

spell.name: Placebind

m.text: a drop of water, a plant seed, and an area at least 100 feet in diameter

entries: Over the course of 8 hours, you guide any number of willing creatures in a ceremony that gives them familiarity with the local area. Participants are able to rest or perform other activities during the ceremony, so long as they do not leave the ceremonial circle and as long as you are able to complete a walk along the circle's edge at least once every 2 hours.

Once cast, the effects of the spell allow the participants to use any of their class features or traits that require a specific terrain type, such as a ranger's Favored Terrain or the wychlaran's Place Magic, on the terrain in a 50-mile radius from the spell's casting. The spell's effect encompasses areas above and below ground, but does not extend to other planes of existence.

This spell does not alter the terrain, only the targets' familiarity with it. For example, a ranger with the Favored Terrain of tundra doesn't suddenly find snow in the desert, they simply treat the terrain in the spell's area of effect as favored, regardless of its type. Abilities requiring the presence of specific physical components such as plants or a storm still require those elements.
The familiarity gained through this spell fades when a creature finishes a long rest.

spell.name: Restore Spirit

m.text: firewood, and rare herbs worth at least 500 gp, which the spell consumes

entries: You perform a ceremony that cleanses and restores the target creature's'' spirit. The ceremony removes the following harmful effects:

items: Any effect causing the target to be blinded, charmed, deafened, exhausted, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, or stunned
Any curses
Possession
Any reductions to the target's ability scores
Any effect reducing the target's maximum hit points
Any negative effects suffered as a result of casting or being subjected to a raise dead or resurrection spells.
Any effects suffered as a result of Wychlaran Communal Bonding being broken

spell.name: Scatterspray
entries: You target a collection of at least six small unsecured objects located within one foot of each other. The objects can be no larger an apple and collectively weigh less than 25 pounds. You cause these objects to fly off in all directions. Creatures within 10 feet of the objects must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or they are struck by the flying items. If the items are hard or sharp, such as stones, sling bullets, coins, or similar, struct creatures take {@damage 2d8} points of bludgeoning damage. If the targeted objects are softer, such as eggs or berries, the spell deals half damage and creatures who fall to 0 hit points from the attack are not killed, but are unconscious and stable instead.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@damage 1d8} for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Shashkah

m.text: a tuft of black wool, a human hair, and a sword

entries: A sword you are holding is imbued with the power of ancient spirits, guiding you in its use. For the duration, you can use your spellcasting ability instead of Strength or Dexterity for the attack and damage rolls of melee attacks using that weapon. The spell ends if you cast it again or if you are not holding the weapon at the end of your turn.

spell.name: Turn Fiend

m.text: a witch bottle containing salt, an ounce of holy water, and chalk worth 50 gp

entries: You unseal the bottle, and a gaseous mixture fills the air around you. Each fiend of Challenge Rating 1 or lower within range must make a Wisdom saving throw. If the creature fails its saving throw, they are turned for 1 minute or until they take any damage.

A turned creature must spend their turns trying to move as far away from you as they can, and they can't willingly move to a space within 30 feet of you. They also can't take reactions. For their action, they can use only the Dash action or try to escape from an effect that prevents them from moving. If there's nowhere to move, the creature uses the Dodge action.
At the end of its turn, a turned creature can repeat this saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th or 6th level, the Challenge Rating of fiends it can affect increases to 2 or lower. If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th or 8th level, the Challenge Rating increases to 4 or lower. If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 9th level, the Challenge Rating increases to 7 or lower.

spell.name: Vulnerability
entries: You touch a creature and mark it with a curse of vulnerability. The target must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or become cursed. While cursed in this way, the target has disadvantage on saving throws they make to resist your spells.

spell.name: Waterspout

m.text: a piece of grass or seaweed twisted into a coil

entries: You conjure a whirling, cylindrical column of water 10 feet in diameter and 60 feet tall rising up from the ground or a body of water. Creatures within 10 feet of the waterspout must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be sucked into the spout. Creatures in water have disadvantage on the saving throw. Any creature that starts its turn inside the spout takes {@damage 2d6} bludgeoning damage and is grappled by the spout (escape DC equal to your spellcasting DC). Targets are restrained while grappled in this way.
As a bonus action on your turn, you can move the spout up to 30 feet in any direction, provided it stays in contact with the ground or a body of water

default: (a) a {@filter any sword|items|type=martial weapon|property=sword} or (b) {@filter any simple weapon|items|type=simple weapon}
(a) {@filter any simple weapon|items|type=simple weapon} or (b) {@item component pouch|phb}
{@item leather armor|phb}, {@item explorer's pack|phb}, and a wychlaran mask

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: Wychlaran spellcasting is a combination of learned knowledge and deep connection with spirits and the land itself. The origin of wychlaran arcane capabilities lies in learned magics such as those practiced by wizards but has evolved over time, and has been tempered with wisdom and passed down in oral traditions and complex rituals. While wychalaren have access to a wide breadth of spells, individuals specialize their knowledge and the rituals needed to form a spiritual connection and change their daily spells are more demanding and therefore more limited on a day-to-day basis. See {@book Spells Rules|PHB|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and the Wychlaran Spells Listing for your {@filter spell list|spells|class=Wychlaran (RCG)}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know two cantrips of your choice from the {@filter wychlaran spell list|spells|class=Wychlaran (RCG)} spell list, as well as the {@spell guidance} and {@spell resistance} cantrips. You learn additional wychlaran cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Wychlaran Class Table.

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries: The Wychlaran Class Table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your wychlaran spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of wychlaran spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the wychlaran spell list. The first time you do so, choose a number of wychlaran spells equal to your wychlaran level + your Wisdom modifier (minimum of one spell). Subsequently, this total increases as your Wychlaran level or your Wisdom modifier increase, but you can only change a limited number of spells on the list per day as described below. Your prepared spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

You can change a number of prepared spells equal to your Wisdom modifier when you finish a long rest, Preparing a new list of wychlaran spells requires time spent in ritual connection with the spirits or with the land: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

For example, if you are a 3rd-level wychlaran, you have two 1st-level and one 2nd-level spell slots. With a Wisdom of 16, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination. If you prepare the 1st-level spell {@spell cure wounds}, you can cast it using a 1st-level or 2nd-level slot. Casting the spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells. With a Wisdom modifier of +3, you can change 3 of the prepared spells on the list whenever you finish a long rest, they need not be the same spells you changed the previous day. The first time you prepare spells after leveling up to 4th level, you prepare one additional spell of your choice from the wychalaran spell list.

The Spell Slots Per Level columns indicate the number of spell slots available to cast per long rest, along with any bonded spell slots you may have available. The "+1" on this list represents the number of bonded spell slots available to you.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your witch spells, as your power comes from your study of the dark arts. You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a witch spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast a wychlaran spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have it prepared.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use {@item sword|phb}, {@item quarterstaff|phb}, or a wychlaran mask as a spellcasting focus for your wychlaran spells.

classFeature.name: Communal Binding
entries: A wychlaran can perform a 1-hour ritual to create a bond between themself and a number of willing creatures. Excluding the wychlaran performing the ritual, the maximum number of creatures that can be included in the ritual is listed in the Communal Binding column in the Wychlaran Class Table. The Communal Binding number increases only with levels in the wychlaran class.

The communal bond lasts until the lead wychlaran performs a new binding ritual or through death. The communal bond is severed for all bonded creatures if the wychlaran dies, and for each individual bonded creature if they die. The ritual can be performed as part of a short or long rest, so long as the wychlaran does not cast spells while performing it. A wychlaran can't perform the Communal Binding ritual more than once every 24 hours.

When the Communal Binding ritual is completed, each bonded creature, including the wychlaran, contributes a number of d3s equal to their proficiency bonus to a communal pool. These dice are used when invoking the communal bindings' effects (see below) and tracked by the wychlaran who performed the ritual. The pool replenishes fully once all bonded creatures have completed a short rest.

The Communal Binding is a spiritual event and not considered magical, and is not affected by {@spell dispel magic} or similar effects. The communal pool is destroyed if the lead wychlaran dies or participates in a new Communal Binding.
{@b Communal Pool Uses}

items: As a bonus action on their turn, any of the bonded creatures can remove one die from the communal pool and add it to their next attack roll, damage roll, or ability check. They must choose the die's use when it is taken from the pool, and before rolling the pool die.

As a reaction when one of the bonded creatures makes a saving throw, that creature and/or the lead wychlaran who can see them can remove one die (each) from the pool and add it to the saving throw. They must do so after the saving throw has been rolled, but before determining the result.
As long as there is at least one die in the communal pool, a wychlaran can add that die to any saving throws made to maintain concentration without expending the die.

entries: {@b Multiple Wychlaran}

No creature, including a wychlaran, can be part of multiple bindings. A wychlaran can be part of a binding performed by another wychlaran; in this case, only one communal pool is formed, and it is controlled by the wychlaran leading the ritual. The binding of a second wychlaran increases the pool die size from d3 to d4, and the binding of a third wychlaran to a d6. Additionally, multiple wychlaran can never have the same Communal Channeling option active simultaneously within the same Communal Binding.
{@b Severed Bonds}

items: When a communal binding is severed as a result of the lead wychlaran's death, all participants suffer a {@dice 1d3} penalty to their attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws, and cannot participate in another Communal Binding until they finish a long rest. The communal pool is also destroyed.

When a communal binding is severed as a result of a bonded creature's death, only the lead wychlaran and that creature suffer the {@dice 1d3} penalty, but neither party suffers any Communal Binding restrictions.

classFeature.name: Bonded Casting
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can extend the benefits of certain spells to those you share a Communal Binding with. Casting in this manner is more strenuous than working normal spells, and only specific spells and separate spell slots can be used for Bonded Casting.
When you use Bonded Casting on your turn, you can take no other actions, bonus actions, or reactions during that turn.

When you use Bonded Casting to cast a spell targeting a creature with whom you share a Communal Binding, you may choose for that spell to affect any number of other creatures that are part of that Communal Binding.
{@b Bonded Spell Slots}

The Wychlaran Class Table shows how many bonded spell slots you have to cast your wychlaran spells of 1st level or higher. These spell slots can also be used for regular casting, but your regular spell slots cannot be used for Bonded Casting.

You regain all expended bonded spell slots when you finish a long rest. You can never gain more bonded spell slots than is listed on the Wychlaran Class Table, and items or features which add or restore spell slots do not add or restore bonded spell slots unless specified.
{@b Bonded Spells}
The Bonded Casting Spells table shows spells that can be used for bonded casting. You always have these spells prepared and they do not count against the number of spells you can prepare.

entries.caption: Bonded Casting Spells
rows: {@spell guidance}, {@spell cure wounds}, {@spell healing word}, {@spell shield of faith}

entries: {@b Bonded Recovery}

Once per day, when you finish a short rest, you can choose expended bonded spell slots to recover. The spell slots can have a combined level that is equal to or less than half your wychlaran level (rounded up).
For example, if you're a 4th-level wychlaran, you can recover up to two levels worth of spell slots. You can recover either a 2nd-level spell slot or two 1st-level spell slots.

classFeature.name: Communal Channeling
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your action to channel energies among those who are part of your Communal Binding, and are within 30 feet of you when the channeling begins. The channeling lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked unconscious or you use an action on your turn to end it. When you begin channeling, you choose one of these options:

items: Commanding Channeling. You take tighter control of the Communal Binding. For the duration of the channeling, only you can use dice from the Communal Pool. Once on each of their turns, other creatures within the Communal Binding can deal additional damage equal to your Charisma modifier to a creature or creatures damaged by one of the bonded creature's spells or attacks.

Protective Channeling. You raise the defenses of the bonded creatures. When you begin channeling and at the start of each of their turns, this feature grants temporary hit points to all other creatures that are part of your Communal Binding. The number of temporary hit points is equal to your Communal Binding number. When a creature loses these temporary hit points, you take psychic damage equal to half your Communal Binding number, rounded down. If multiple creatures lose these hit points simultaneously, the total damage you take is capped at your Communal Binding number for that instance. Damage you take from Protective Channeling ignores resistance and immunity, but does not cause you to make saving throws to maintain concentration.

Psychic Channeling. You form a strong telepathic connection with the bonded creatures. For the duration of the channeling, all creatures within your Communal Bond can communicate telepathically, regardless of distance. The connection formed enables the affected creatures to perform more complex maneuvers by giving them awareness of what their comrades are about to do. Additionally, as a bonus action on their turn, a bonded creature can use the senses of another bonded creature instead of their own until the end of their own turn. For example, a human can gain a dwarf's darkvision.

classFeature.name: Wychlaran Praxis
entries: At 3rd level, you choose the set of teachings and customs you practice in your daily life as a wychlaran. The choice of praxis informs all aspects of your powers, from additional spells you learn from spirits, to how you lead your communal binding, to the way you use constructs. The Praxis of Tradition is the time-honored path for most hathrans, while the Praxis of Power is the nonconformist path typically taken by durthans.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Place Magic
entries: Starting at 5th level, you are able to draw on the magic of the land itself to help you cast your magics. While you are located in Rashemen, you can cast any wychlaran ritual spell without having it prepared.
Additionally, once per short rest, you can cast one wychlaran spell you don't have prepared using an appropriate spell slot.

classFeature.name: Unweave (1 use)
entries: The years of resistance and opposition to the Thayan wizards have taught the wychlaran to combat magic.

Starting at 6th level, you can use your action to cast {@spell dispel magic} at its lowest level, or your reaction to cast {@spell counterspell} at its lowest level, without using a spell slot, any components, or having the spell prepared.

Additionally, if the spell or effect you are attempting to unweave is of the necromancy or enchantment schools and requires you to make an ability check as part of casting {@spell dispel magic} or {@spell counterspell}, you can add your proficiency bonus to the ability check.
You may use this feature once and regain any expended uses when you finish a short rest. You gain additional uses of Unweave at 9th and 13th levels in this class.

classFeature.name: Wychlaran Praxis Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain another feature from your Praxis.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Unweave (2 uses)
entries: You gain an additional use of Unweave at 9th level in this class.

classFeature.name: Repurpose Construct
entries: Starting at 10th level, ancient Raumatharian knowledge of constructs allows you to make use of existing constructs. When you defeat a construct and it is not entirely destroyed, you can attempt to magically re-purpose it to serve you. You can't attempt to repurpose a construct with a Challenge Rating greater than half your wychlaran level (rounded up).

The repurposing attempt takes 1 minute, during which you must remain within 5 feet of the construct and can't cast any spells. At the end of the minute, make a Wisdom (Arcana) check with a DC equal to 10 plus the construct's Challenge Rating. On failure, the construct is not re-animated and can't be targeted by this feature again.

On a success, you gain control of the construct, with the following changes: the construct no longer has its knowledge or personality, it has only half of its average hit points and can never regain hit points by any means short of a wish spell. It has an Armor Class 2 points lower than listed in its stat block. The construct acts immediately after you in initiative, and can move, dodge, and use any reactions on its own, but taking other actions requires you take a bonus action to command it to do so on its turn.

The construct is held together by magic and falls apart after 8 hours or earlier if you repurpose a different construct. Additionally, it can be destroyed by the {@spell dispel magic} spell or similar effects as a spell equal to its Challenge Rating.
Once you've successfully repurposed a construct, you can't do so again until you finish a short rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Unweave (3 uses)
entries: You gain an additional use of Unweave at 13th level in this class.

classFeature.name: Wychlaran Praxis Feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain another feature from your Praxis.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Wychlaran Praxis Feature
entries: At 18th level, you gain another feature from your Praxis.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Coven
entries: At 20th level, your Communal Binding can empower whole communities.

items: There is no longer a limit to the number of creatures that can be part of your Communal Binding.
When at least 6 other creatures are part of your Communal Binding, the Communal Pool has unlimited dice.
When at least 6 other creatures are part of your Communal Binding, other wychlaran within the binding can also use the pool as though they were the binding's leads.

entries: Having a 4th, 5th, or 6th wychlaran as part of your Communal Binding can now increase the Communal Pool die to a d8, d10, and d12 respectively.

subclassFeature.name: Secret Ways
entries: When you adopt the Praxis of Power at 3rd level, you become proficient in the Deception and Stealth skills.

subclassFeature.name: Praxis of Power
entries: The Praxis of Power lets you forge an independent path, seeking out hidden or forbidden knowledge to achieve your goals.
{@b Praxis Spells}

You gain praxis spells at the wychlaran levels listed in the Praxis of Power Spells table. You gain both standard and Bonded Casting spells from your praxis. Once you gain a praxis spell, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day.
If you have a praxis spell that doesn't appear on the wychlaran spell list, the spell is nonetheless a wychlaran spell for you.

entries.caption: Praxis of Power Spells
rows: {@spell bane}, {@spell dissonant whispers}, {@spell inflict wounds}, {@spell heat metal}, {@spell pass without trace}, {@spell phantasmal force}
{@spell elemental weapon}, {@spell summon lesser demons|xge}, {@spell summon shadowspawn|tce}
{@spell compulsion}, {@spell summon aberration|tce}, {@spell summon greater demon|xge}

subclassFeature.name: Communal Channeling Enhancements
entries: Your Praxis of Power leads you to focus on harnessing personal power from your channeling. You learn to improve your communal channeling in subtle ways. An enhancement to each channeling option is available for you starting when you adopt this Praxis at 3rd level. You choose one of these options when you gain this feature, a second at 9th level, and the third at 11th level.
{@b Draw Power}
{@i Commanding Channeling Enhancement.}

While your Commanding Channeling is active, as a reaction when you deal damage, you can add the number of communal pool dice up to your communal binding number to the damage dealt by one of your attacks or wychlaran spells.
{@b Draw Protection}
{@i Protective Channelling Enhancement}

While your Protective Channeling is active, as a reaction when you take damage from an enemy, you can reduce the temporary hit points on any number of willing creatures in your Communal Binding to 0, and then reduce the damage you take by the same amount. The affected bonded creatures can't gain temporary hit points by any means until the start of your next turn.
{@b Masterplan}
{@i Psychic Channelling Enhancement}

When you roll initiative and you are not surprised, you can use your reaction to immediately begin your Psychic Channeling. Additionally, you may switch the initiatives of willing bonded creatures, including yourself, in any way you see fit.

subclassFeature.name: Demonstrate Power
entries: Starting at 7th level, you can use the power you exude to dissuade others from hostile action. As an action, you can expend a spell slot of any level and attempt to threaten a creature with your arcane power.

If the creature's Challenge Rating is equal to or less than the level of slot expended, the creature refuses to take any action harmful to you and your allies for 24 hours and leaves the area unless it is in its lair or residence.

If however, the creature's Challenge Rating is higher than the level of the expended spell slot, for the next minute, you can use your reaction to the first hostile action by the creature against you or your allies to cast a spell with the previously expended spell slot;  the spell must have a regular casting time of 1 action, be of the same or lower level as the expended slot, and target only that creature.

subclassFeature.name: Personal Guardian
entries: Starting at 14th level, when you successfully repurpose a construct with a Challenge Rating of 7 or higher, you can repurpose it as a {@creature shield guardian} for yourself. The repurposed construct is subject to all penalties of the Repurpose Construct feature, including inability to regain hit points, but uses the {@creature shield guardian} statistics instead of the original construct's. The {@creature shield guardian} is bound to you and does not require a control amulet. Unlike a standard repurposed construct, the {@creature shield guardian} lasts until it is reduced to 0 hit points, is dispelled, or you repurpose a different construct.

subclassFeature.name: Place Power
entries: Starting at 18th level, when you finish a long rest in Rashemen, you can commune with the Rashemi spirits to begin the day with the {@spell gate} and {@spell meteor swarm} spells prepared. These spells count as wychlaran spells for you, and don't count against the number of spells you can prepare.

Alternatively, or if you are not in Rashemen, when you finish your long rest, you can commune with the local spirits. The DM chooses one spell of 7th or 8th level from any spell list that is relevant to either the theme or the former inhabitants of the region and you begin the day with this spell prepared; it counts a wychlaran spell for you, and does not count against the number of spells known. For example, communing with the spirits of the Plane of Fire may result in preparing the {@spell fire storm} spell, while communing with the spirits of a storm giant kingdom might result in {@spell control weather}. In the unlikely event that the location you're in has never been inhabited—such as a demiplane—this ability may yield no additional spells.

subclassFeature.name: Fortitude
entries: When you adopt the Praxis of Tradition at 3rd level, you learn traditional meditation techniques that fortify the body and spirit. Your hit point maximum increases by 3, and increases by 1 again whenever you gain a level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Praxis of Tradition
entries: The Praxis of Tradition focuses on the protection and leadership of your people.

You gain praxis spells at the wychlaran levels listed in the Praxis of Tradition Spells table. You gain both standard and Bonded Casting spells from your praxis. Once you gain a praxis spell, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day.
If you have a praxis spell that doesn't appear on the wychlaran spell list, the spell is nonetheless a wychlaran spell for you.

entries.caption: Praxis of Tradition Spells
rows: {@spell animal friendship}, {@spell beast bond|xge}, {@spell calm emotions}, {@spell sanctuary}, {@spell spike growth}, {@spell summon beast|tce}
{@spell beacon of hope}, {@spell call lightning}, {@spell life transference|xge}
{@spell dominate beast}, {@spell guardian of nature|xge}, {@spell stone shape}
{@spell bones of the earth|xge}, {@spell wind walk}

entries.caption: Bonded Casting Spells
rows: {@spell resistance}, {@spell protection from evil and good}

subclassFeature.name: Communal Channeling Enhancements
entries: You learn to improve your communal channeling in subtle ways. An enhancement to each channelling option is available for you starting when you adopt this Praxis at 3rd level. You choose one of these options when you gain this feature, a second at 9th, and the third at 11th level.
{@b Voice of Reason}
{@i Commanding Channeling Enhancement.}

While your Commanding Channeling is active, and you use a communal pool die on another creature, instead of using one die, you can use a number of dice equal to half your Communal Binding number (rounded up).
{@b Soothing Presence}
{@i Protective Channelling Enhancement}

While your Protective Channeling is active, the number of temporary hit points granted increases by your communal pool die. Additionally, you are resistant to psychic damage, including that dealt by your communal channeling.
{@b Burden of Leadership}
{@i Psychic Channelling Enhancement}

While your Psychic Channeling is active, as reaction at the start of your turn, you can choose to switch places in initiative with one bonded creature that has a lower initiative than you. The change in initiative lasts until the end of the combat. Once used, this feature can't be used again until the next time you roll initiative.

subclassFeature.name: Declare Presence
entries: Starting at 7th level, the weight of your presence is felt not only by the people of Rashemen, but by any intelligent creature. As an action, you speak your name and title (as appropriate) outloud. Your voice can be heard up to 60 feet away, including through nonmagical barriers such as stone up to 5 feet thick. For the next 10 minutes, you have advantage on Charisma checks made to interact with any creature that heard your declaration that has an Intelligence of 4 higher and speaks at least one language. Additionally, if you are surprised during this period, you do not lose the ability to use your reaction as a result of being surprised.

subclassFeature.name: Protective Construct
entries: Starting at 14th level, you are able to use a construct under your control to protect your allies. As a reaction when a creature you can see is hit by an attack, you command your construct to intercept the attack. The construct must use its reaction to do so. If the construct is within 5 feet of the target, it takes twice the attack's damage. If the construct is more than 5 feet away, it may move up to its speed as part of its reaction.

subclassFeature.name: Place Wisdom
entries: Starting at 18th level, when you finish a long rest in Rashemen, you can commune with the Rashemi spirits to begin the day with the {@spell shapechange} and {@spell true resurrection} spells prepared. These spells count as wychlaran spells for you, and don't count against the number of spells you can prepare.

Alternatively, or if you are not in Rashemen, when you finish your long rest, you can commune with the local spirits. The DM chooses one spell of 7th or 8th level from any spell list that is relevant to either the theme or the former inhabitants of the region and you begin the day with this spell prepared; it counts a wychlaran spell for you, and does not count against the number of spells known. For example, communing with the spirits of the Plane of Fire may result in preparing the {@spell fire storm} spell, while communing with the spirits of a storm giant kingdom might result in {@spell control weather}. In the unlikely event that the location you're in has never been inhabited—such as a demiplane—this ability may yield no additional spells.

subclassFeature.name: Telthor Companion
entries: Rashemen is a land filled with nature spirits. Some, known as telthors, are sacred guardian spirits protecting locations, berserker lodges, and in some cases, individuals. A few rare witches can form a connection with these spirits who become the caster's bonded protector.
Interestingly, many durthans who worked secretly against wychlaran rule followed this tradition, binding darker spirits of the country to their will.

subclassFeature.name: Spiritual Companion
entries: When you adopt this tradition at 2nd level, you gain a spiritual companion called a telthor. Your telthor can take the form of any beast (not including swarms) with a CR of 1/2 or less. The companion uses the stats of your chosen beast with the following changes:

items: Your telthor's type is fey, instead of beast.
Your telthor has a number of hit dice equal to your own, and gains an additional hit die whenever you gain a level in this class.
You and your telthor can communicate telepathically, as long as you are within 100 feet.

entries: After choosing the form your telthor takes, you cannot change it. Your telthor acts independently of you, but it always obeys your commands. In combat, it makes its own initiative checks and acts on its own turn. As long as you and your telthor are within 30 feet of each other, you can make any spell you cast that targets only you also target your telthor. If it is of a suitable size, your telthor can also serve you as a mount both in and out of combat.

As an action, as long as you are within 100 feet of your telthor, you can see and hear through its eyes and ears until the start of your next turn. During this time, you are deaf and blind with regard to your own senses, but gain the benefits of any special senses your telthor has.

When your telthor drops to 0 hit points, it disappears, leaving behind no physical form. You can also dismiss it at any time as an action, causing it to disappear. In either case, it can be resummoned by performing a ritual during a long rest, at the end of which your telthor reappears, restored to its hit point maximum.
At 6th level, you gain a second telthor companion, which can take the form of any beast (not including swarms) with a CR of 1 or less.

subclassFeature.name: Heart of Ice
entries: By the time you reach 6th level, your connection to the magic you wield grants you and your telthor resistance to cold damage. Additionally, spells you cast that deal cold damage ignore resistances.

subclassFeature.name: Irresistible
entries: As your knowledge of the arcane grows, your magic becomes harder for others to resist. Starting at 10th level, whenever you cast a wizard spell that requires targets to make a saving throw, you can choose to force all targets to make the saving throw with disadvantage. Once you've used this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Telthor Coordination
entries: By 14th level, your telthor have become an irreplaceable part of your combat tactics. Whenever you cast a spell or make a weapon attack, one of your telthor can use their reaction to move up to 10 feet and make an attack against a creature within range.

subclassFeature.name: Paried Witch
entries: Rashemi culture recognizes that one individual's strength can balance another's weakness. It is not uncommon for witches to travel with a trusted companion. Witches of importance, or those charged with urgent tasks, may have companions thrust upon them by elders concerned for their safety. The wychlaran wizards recognize the benefits of such pairings and often forge long lasting relationships with those charged with their care.

subclassFeature.name: Cohort
entries: Starting when you adopt this tradition at 2nd level, you are assigned a cohort by the elders of the wychlaran. As you grow in power, so will your cohort, so that they might serve you as long as they can. When you gain this feature, choose one of the following types: arcanist, martialist, or sneak. The type you choose determines the stat blocks your cohort will use as you gain more levels in this class, as shown on the table below.

Your cohort must be a humanoid native of Rashemen and share at least one language with you, but you can choose or randomly select specific details such as their race or gender. Your cohort would risk their life to protect you, and follows your orders to the best of their ability. In combat, they roll their own initiative and act on their own turn. Out of combat they may run small errands or scout out an area, but they will not willingly travel more than a few miles away from the one they are sworn to protect.
If your cohort dies and is not revived, you must return to a populated area (such as a city or village) and spend {@dice 2d6} days searching for another suitable cohort.

subclassFeature.name: The Land Provides
entries: By the time you reach 6th level, your spiritual connection to the land has granted you and your cohort protection against those who would use its power against you. You both gain resistance to poison damage, and are immune to the poisoned condition.

subclassFeature.name: Born Leader
entries: With your title comes authority, and at 10th level you learn a new way to wield it. As an action, you can issue a simple command (such as those detailed in the command spell) to a number of creatures equal to double your Charisma modifier. Each target must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC, or be magically compelled to carry out the command for a number of rounds equal to your Charisma modifier.
At the end of each of their turns for the duration, targeted creatures can repeat the Wisdom saving throw, ending the effect on themselves on a success.

On each of your turns for the duration, you can issue a new command that must be able to be performed in one round. For the following round, targeted creatures will instead perform the new command on their turn.
Once you've used this feature, you must finish a long rest before doing so again.

subclassFeature.name: Intimidating Aura
entries: By 14th level, you exude an aura of power and importance that inspires fear and awe in those around you. As long as you aren't incapacitated, hostile creatures who enter or begin their turn in a space within 10 feet of you must make a Wisdom saving throw or become frightened of you until the beginning of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Reborn
entries: You were reincarnated. Either you were chosen by nature, by fate, or by the casting of magics, but you've returned to the world in a new body. What new experiences will you try? What old memories linger on? There is a bright world out there for you to rediscover.

subclassFeature.name: Past Life
entries: You express a feature from one of your former lives. Select one NPC race from the NPC Features table in chapter 9 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|dmg|9|NPC Stat Blocks}. For the next 10 minutes, you gain the features listed for that race in addition to your own. You do not gain the race's ability modifiers. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier, and regain all uses after finishing a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Reborn Magic
entries: You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Reborn Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.
Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be a spell on the sorcerer spell list.

subclassFeature.name: Knowledge Reborn
entries: Whenever you use your Past Life feature, you select one of the following features which also manifests for the duration of the feature. Once you manifest a class feature, you cannot choose that class again for this feature until you finish a long rest.

entries.caption: Knowledge Reborn Abilities
rows: You gain proficiency with a single set of tools of your choice. They are also a spellcasting focus for you.
You have advantage on Dexterity saving throws against effects that you can see, such as traps and spells. To gain this benefit, you can't be blinded, deafened, or incapacitated.
You can add half your proficiency bonus, rounded down, to any ability check in which you are not proficient.
Exchange up to 2 of your cantrips for cleric cantrips.
Exchange up to 2 of your cantrips for druid cantrips.
On your turn, you can use a bonus action to regain hit points equal to {@dice 1d10} + your sorcerer level. Once you use this feature, Knowledge Reborn ends.
Your movement increases by 5 feet and your unarmed attacks deal {@dice 1d4} damage.
You ignore difficult terrain from natural sources, such as overgrown underbrush, but not from spells, such as entangle.

Choose one of the following skills. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for ability checks made with that skill: Acrobatics, Athletics, Deception, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Perception, Performance, Persuasion, Sleight of Hand, and Stealth.
When you cast a spell, you can cast it as though you used a spell slot 1 level higher. If you do, Knowledge Reborn ends.
When Knowledge Reborn ends, you regain a 1st-or 2nd-level spell slot.
You can cast any ritual from the Wychlaran spell list as long as you are in Rashemen. If you do, Knowledge Reborn ends.

subclassFeature.name: Reborn Defense
entries: You can expend a use of your Past Lives feature to become proficient in saving throws and ability checks in an ability of your choice for 10 minutes.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerer's Bloodline
entries: You can use 3 sorcery points to regain a use of your Past Lives feature. You can expend a use of your Past Lives feature to gain 2 sorcery points.

subclassFeature.name: Final Form
entries: You can cast polymorph on yourself without requiring any components or using a spell slot. You can use this form to take actions which require hands or speech, allowing you to talk and cast spells while polymorphed in this way.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest, unless you spend 5 sorcery points to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Raumathari Battlemage
entries: The Raumathari battlemages of old were an order of sorcerers who mastered an innate connection to the principles of war and the art of combat. The very heat of battle ran in their blood, and through intense focus and constant practice they managed to become some of the most fearsome warriors and spellcasters in all of Faern. Their bloodlines still linger today. Those that seek out the teachings of the Raumathari battlemages can revive their legacy once more, becoming the living embodiment of sword and spell.

subclassFeature.name: Sword Focus
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can create a magical bond between yourself and one melee weapon allowing you to transform the weapon into an extension of yourself. During a long rest, you can spend 1 hour performing this ritual. The weapon must be within your reach throughout the ritual, at the conclusion of which you touch the weapon and forge the bond.

While bonded to this weapon, when you attack with that weapon, you are proficient with it and you can use it as a spellcasting focus. When you make an attack using this weapon, you can use your Charisma modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity, for the attack and damage rolls, and the weapon counts as magical for the purpose of overcoming damage immunities and resistances.
You can only bond to one weapon at a time this way. If you attempt bond yourself to a new weapon, you must end your bond with the previous one.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Combat
entries: By channeling your magical abilities through your bonded weapon, you convert your innate magical prowess into martial mastery. Starting at 1st level, as long as you hold your bonded weapon, you gain a bonus to your AC equal to your Charisma modifier as long as you aren't wearing armor.

Once you reach 3rd level, you can spend 2 sorcery points to envelop your bonded weapon in magical energy. Choose one damage type: acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder. For the next minute, your bonded weapon deals an additional {@damage 1d6} damage of the chosen type to any target you hit with the weapon. As a bonus action, you can change the damage type, choosing from the options above.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Warrior's Soul
entries: You have the heart of a warrior, and that dauntless spirit spurs you to overcome any trial.

Starting at 14th level, you can no longer be frightened. Additionally, when you roll a Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution saving throw, you can spend 3 sorcery points to give yourself advantage on the saving throw.

subclassFeature.name: Wardbreaker's Strike
entries: You can sever your foe's strength with a simple swing of your weapon. Starting at 18th level, when you hit a creature with your bonded weapon, you can spend 6 sorcery points to weaken the creature's resistance against your spells. If you do, the next time you damage that creature with a spell, the creature has vulnerability to all of that spell's damage.

subclassFeature.name: Pledge Bonded Conclave
entries: Pairing up with your brother or sister is a very common sight in Rashemen. Still, there are some who are selfless beyond all measure. They will go to great lengths to protect each other, operating so efficiently that one could mistake them as a single mind bound to two bodies.

entries.name: Pledge Bonded Spells
entries: You learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Pledge-Bonded Spells table. Each spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

entries.caption: Pledge Bonded Spells
rows: {@spell dispel evil and good}, {@spell tree stride}

subclassFeature.name: Honor Pledge
entries: When you finish a long rest with a willing creature who started that same long rest with you, you can pledge yourself to them. While you are within 5 feet of your bond, they gain a +2 bonus to their Armor Class. Additionally, you can cast spells with a range of self or touch on your bond as long as you're on the same plane of existence.
This effect ends if you pledge yourself to another creature, if either your or your bond dies, or your bond chooses to end the effect.

subclassFeature.name: Heartshield
entries: If you can see your bond and are within 120 feet of them and they are targeted by a spell or attack you can see, you can use your reaction to move up to your speed directly towards them. This movement does not provoke opportunity attacks. If you end within 5 feet of your bond, the spell or attack targets you instead.

subclassFeature.name: Teamwork Attacks
entries: You and your bond gain the following benefits as long as you are within 30 feet of each other:

items: When you both make initiative checks, you can swap your results.

If you or your bond hits with an attack, the next time either of you makes an attack roll and misses that target, the attack still deals damage equal to the ability modifier used in the attack. This lasts until you or your bond attacks a different target.

subclassFeature.name: Unparalleled Pair
entries: Your Teamwork Attacks feature improves as follows:

items: Teamwork Attacks' range increases to 60 feet.
When you or your bond makes an attack against a creature, you or your bond can use a reaction to make a weapon attack or cast a cantrip against the same target.

entries: Additionally, your Honor Pledge improves as follows:

items: You and your bond have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects as long as you are within 5 feet of each other.

subclassFeature.name: Lend Pair
entries: As an action, you grant most of your ranger features to your bond. For the next hour, they gain the following benefits from your class:

items: Favored Enemy against each creature type you have selected
Natural Explorer with each type of favored terrain you have selected
One of your Fighting Styles
Land's Stride
Hide in Plain Sight
Vanish

entries: When this ability ends, your Honor Pledge ability ends as well.

subclassFeature.name: Vremyonni
entries: Spellcasters who can't join the hathran are often exiled from their communities. The safety of their community members largely depends on knowing that spellcasters can be responsible for their actions, that they understand the full weight of their powers.

While exiled, most spellcasting Rashemi fall into one of two groups: those who exile themselves, leaving Rashemen forever, or those who join the vremyonni: an elite group of spellcasters who use their powers to enhance magic items for their allies. The hathrans aren't going to let such a powerful resource go to waste either; in times of need, the vremyonni are bound to the witches where their powers can be more purposefully directed.

subclassFeature.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with smith's tools. If you already have this proficiency, you gain proficiency with one other type of artisan's tools of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Battle Binding
entries: You craft a new tool known as a battle wrap using a ritual known only to the vremyonni. This wrap can be placed around mundane items to grant them magical fortifications or to bind to another spellcaster, allowing you to fight as a pair.

If the wrap is lost or destroyed, you can craft a new one as part of a short rest with 100gp worth of materials, or as part of a long rest (requiring no gold). The wrap's AC is equal to the AC of the individual holding the bonded item or 10 if the item is not held. The wrap has hit points equal to 5 x your artificer level and gains resistance to all damage starting at 10th level.

As part of a short rest, you can bind your battle wrap around a single weapon or part of a suit of armor. Weapons wrapped in this way deal {@damage 1d6} extra damage of the weapon's damage type. Each time your proficiency modifier increases, the weapon deals an extra die of damage (up to {@damage 5d6} with a proficiency modifier of +6). Armor wrapped in this way provides resistance against your choice of the following: bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage.
You can create an additional wrap at levels 9 and 14.

subclassFeature.name: Battle Caster
entries: If you cast an artificer cantrip, you can use your bonus action to cast a second artificer cantrip you know.

subclassFeature.name: Power Bound
entries: You can use your battle wrap to attach yourself to another willing creature who can cast spells. This process takes 10 minutes and can only be ended as part of a short or long rest, or if either of you die.
While bound in this way, either of you can use your action to gain the following benefits:

items: If one of you moves (on their own volition or by using magic), the other immediately teleports to an open space within 5 feet of the bound partner. If the creature is unwilling to teleport, the other has their speed reduced to 0 until the end of turn.
You both have resistance to all damage except psychic. Whenever one bound partner takes damage, the other takes the same amount of damage.
You both have advantage on saving throws.

entries: These benefits last 10 minutes or until a creature no longer consents to the binding, ending the effect immediately.

subclassFeature.name: Potential Unbound
entries: As an action, you cause your battle binding to flare brightly with energy. For 10 minutes, the following changes apply to your binding and whatever it is bound upon:

items: Weapons grant +3 to attack.
Armor grants resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage, as well as granting +2 to AC.
If you are bound to a willing spellcaster, if either of you tries to cast a spell, they can use a spell slot from the other bound creature if the other creature consents.

entries: After the 10 minutes elapses, the binding burns away to ashes.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Runescarred
entries: Runescarred berserkers are a fearsome combatant on the battlefield. Blessed with patronage from the Wychlaran, their bodies are infused with magic, ready to be unleashed: a living weapon, with enhanced capabilities and potential. While sometimes actual scars are created during the runescarring ritual, the practice is not required to bond the magic to the body. All that is required is an indomitable will, an unwavering conviction, and the constitution to hold raw magic back from its natural urge to burst forth.

subclassFeature.name: Runescars
entries: Runescarred berserkers are infused with limited magical aptitude from their hathran patron. This magic takes the form of runescars, which are temporary magical sigils and glyphs on the host's body, which tap into the bearer's internal strength to fuel the magic. You know a specific set of spells based on your barbarian level, as shown in the Runescarred Spells table below. During a long rest, you inscribe a number of these spells that you know onto your body in the form of magical runes, up to your proficiency bonus.

You cast any spell you have inscribed at its lowest level. You can cast and concentrate on these spells while raging. Your rage doesn't end early if you cast a spell on your turn. Spells you cast in this way have a range of self if they didn't already. You must finish a short or long rest before using this feature again.
At 6th level, you gain an additional use of this feature, and can replace two inscribed runescar spells with two other spells of your choice during a short rest.
{@b {@i Runescar Ability.}} Constitution is your spellcasting ability for spells you cast with your Runescars feature. You use your Constitution whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability.

entries.caption: Runescarred Spells
rows: {@spell absorb elements|xge}, {@spell cure wounds}, {@spell divine favor}
{@spell crusader's mantle}, {@spell fly}, {@spell protection from energy}
{@spell death ward}, {@spell freedom of movement}, {@spell stoneskin}

subclassFeature.name: Runic Power
entries: While benefiting from the effects of a spell cast with your Runescars feature, your weapon attacks are considered magical for the purposes of overcoming resistances.

subclassFeature.name: Witch Strength
entries: While raging, you can use your bonus action to make a melee spell attack against a creature you can see within 10 feet of you, as you allow raw magic to lash out from your body. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d12} + your Constitution modifier force damage. If the target is Large or smaller, they are pulled to the nearest unoccupied space within 5 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: Reckless Wards
entries: When you are forced to make a saving throw against a spell or magical effect and fail, you can use your reaction to choose to succeed instead. When you do, roll on the Reckless Magic table to determine a magical effect to be produced.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain expended uses after completing a long rest.

entries.caption: Reckless Magic
rows: The runes on your body sunder, causing you to lose one use of your Runescars feature. If no uses are remaining, you take {@damage 2d10} psychic damage.
Magical feedback from the runes on your body causes you to become stunned until the end of your next turn.
You must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or your rage ends.
You can speak only in animal noises until the end of your next turn, but this does not affect any of your Runescarred features.
You gain resistance to the damage dealt by the originating effect, if any.
Magical energy spewing from the runes coalesces around the originating effect and disperse it, turning the failed saving throw into a success

The runes on your body surge, allowing you to regain an expended use of your Runescar feature. If this would bring you above your maximum number of uses, you instead gain {@dice 2d10} temporary hit points.

subclassFeature.name: College of Appartitions
entries: Bards who belong to the College of Apparitions invoke apparitions with the magic of their performance. The appearance of the phantoms answering the bard's call reflect the performer's nature. Those with ties to the land might call forth spirits of nature manifesting as ethereal animals floating serenely nearby. Others summon ghostly warrior ancestors ready for combat. Those who carry a taint of darkness may sing haunting dirges invoking the reluctant spirits of the damned.

subclassFeature.name: Call the Spirits
entries: When you join the College of Apparitions at 3rd level, you learn one additional cantrip chosen from {@spell dancing lights}, {@spell mage hand}, or {@spell minor illusion}.
You also learn the spells {@spell find familiar} and {@spell unseen servant}. These spells count as bard spells for you but don't count against the number of bard spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Shielding Song
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can call upon the spirits to distract your enemies. When a creature that you can see within 60 feet of you makes an attack roll, you can use your reaction to expend one of your uses of Bardic Inspiration to cause the attack to be at disadvantage. You can choose to use this feature after the creature makes its roll, but before the DM determines whether the attack roll hits.

subclassFeature.name: Voice of the Wind
entries: At 6th level, your affinity with the spirits allows you to call them to invoke magical effects that defy gravity. You learn the spells {@spell feather fall}, {@spell levitate}, and {@spell fly}. These spells count as bard spells for you but don't count against the number of bard spells you know. Additionally, you may cast one of these spells without expending a spell slot, but you can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Spiritual Aura
entries: Starting at 14th level, as a bonus action, you sing a haunting melody calling forth spirits of the land to create a swirling aura of spiritual protection that lasts until the end of your next turn. On subsequent turns, you can use a bonus action to continue your melody and extend its duration for an additional turn. The spiritual aura extends out from you to a distance of 15 feet.

While the aura exists, creatures you designate as allies have advantage on all saving throws, gain half cover from attacks originating within the aura, and have three-quarters cover on attacks from outside the aura. Creatures within the aura not designated as an ally have disadvantage on saving throws and must spend 3 feet of movement for every 1 foot they move.

You can use your action to command the spirits to grab hold of one target within the aura. The target must succeed on a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC or become restrained until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Nydeshka
entries: Barbarians who are unable to control their rage are labeled nydeshka: powerful berserkers but dangerous to their allies. Hathran put these dangerous combatants on the front lines with blunted swords, all but guaranteeing their destruction.

However, there are some who pull themselves back from the precipice and learn to hone their rage. Surviving battle after battle, their blunted swords become a trophy, a mark of honor. Acting as a symbol of rage, they're able to inspire their comrades to rage-like states themselves.

entries.name: Moment of Inspiration
entries: Most nydeshka end up dead, as being placed in life-threatening situations tends to do. But for those who survive, there comes flashes of inspiration. These shards of hope help guide the wayward warrior back onto a path of coexistence with the rest of their Rashemi brethren. This is the moment you stopped being a berserker, and dedicated yourself to the paladin oath presented here.
Use the table below to determine what your moment of inspiration was by either choosing an option, rolling randomly, or using the table to inspire a moment of your own design.

rows: You saw the fear in the eyes of a fellow warrior, knocked to the ground by your ferocity. You saw a vision of yourself in their position, and realized you needed to control your rage before you end up being your own demise.

The battlefield was empty, like a grave, when your rage wore off. Happily surveying the destruction as you counted the corpses of your foes, you spied the body of a young Rashemi. At first, you cursed your foes, but you recognized the damage done as your own. This youth must have been sent to gather you but only met your wrath. This can never happen again.

Blood-red fury was all you could see, as the mountain of bodies grew ever higher. A never-ending swath of useless combatants sent by your enemies. As the pile expanded, you recognized that the bodies were falling in the shape of a familiar sigil. Without warning, you blacked out and can remember only a heavenly voice telling you that your path diverged that day, that you were saved from your own anger. When you woke, the battle was over and you understood more about yourself than you ever imagined.

Battles had been few and far between, so those above your station would send you to handle monstrosities in the wilds. Word of an undead spirit harassing traders brought you to an Owl Telthor. You tried hard, but could not scratch the beast-lord. However, as you laid with ragged breath, something caused the great creature to take pity upon you. Touching your forehead with a glowing claw, your heart was made light; your unending rage began to quench.

A djemma designed to take you as far from home as possible: the perfect way to remove a dangerous element like yourself from everyday life. You spent weeks wandering the world, seeing cultures you never imagined existed.
